Notes: Schools have been open for class X and XII students to complete their exams.    All schools across the country are to open on April 25th to allow children to attain full immunity after the second dose of vaccination in the first week of April.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319202750/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

Bhutan is gradually opening up.    Starting April 4, schools of Classes VII, VIII, IX, X and XII must open in the first phase.     Primary schools (Classes PP to VI) will start from April 18. However, children who are unvaccinated, and the day care and ECCD centres, must wait for another 10 days to resume.    All colleges and institutions must open from April 4 or soon after, based on the preparation time required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

Schools have been open for class X and XII students to complete their exams.    All schools across the country are to open on April 25th to allow children to attain full immunity after the second dose of vaccination in the first week of April.    https://archive.ph/7bB3Z

Bhutan is gradually opening up. As of Mar 21, 2022    Except for the entertainment centers all business entities, including snooker and video game parlors can operate with 9PM as revised curfew.  Gym, yoga and similar fitness centres can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone.  In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff.   All private and public offices in the Dzongkhags that have remained closed so far must open from Monday, 21st March    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403033854/https:/www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Bhutan is gradually opening up.  Except for the entertainment centers all business entities, including snooker and video game parlors can operate with 9 PM as the revised curfew. Gym, yoga, and similar fitness centers can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone. In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies, and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff.  All private and public offices in the Dzongkhags that have remained closed so far must open starting from Monday, 21st March. All offices are to be fully operational by 11th April.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Bhutan is gradually opening up.  Except for the entertainment centers all business entities, including snooker and video game parlors can operate with 9 PM as the revised curfew. Gym, yoga, and similar fitness centers can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone. In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies, and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff.  All private and public offices in the Dzongkhags that have remained closed so far must open starting from Monday, 21st March. All offices are to be fully operational by 11th April.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Bhutan has a plan for new phase of COVID 19 management. Public events are not allowed.    April 25: all sporting events will be allowed without spectators    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319202750/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320193452/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/20-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%8C%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AB/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319200758/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/16-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AE%F0%9D%90%9B%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9C-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%9E-pmo/

Bhutan is opening up gradually. As of Mar 28, 2022    All indoor and outdoor sporting activities will be permitted but without spectators. Tournaments are not allowed for now.    Archery and khuru are allowed but must be kept at a maximum of 10 players per match, until the final relaxation.    All workshops, seminars and conferences to be held virtually.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

There are no specific stay-at-home and gatherings requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

Bhutan has a plan for new phase of COVID 19 management    March 21: Movement of private cars within the respective mega-zone is allowed. Those who need to drive beyond the mega-zone for emergency reasons must produce documents or any evidence for verification on the ground. All inter-district travels are allowed.All public busses must be operational to facilitate the travels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320193452/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/20-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%8C%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AB/

Bhutan is opening up gradually. As of March 28, 2022    All public transport services must resume its routine schedule.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

Taxis could ferry people within the mega zone and identified government, corporate and private employees could attend from their offices. In addition to taxis, the movement of private cars within the respective mega-zone is allowed. Those who need to drive beyond the mega-zone for emergency reasons must produce documents or any evidence for verification on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

There are no specific stay at home requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan, however, government is asking people to exercise caution.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319202750/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319200758/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/16-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AE%F0%9D%90%9B%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9C-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%9E-pmo/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320193452/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/20-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%8C%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AB/

There are no specific stay-at-home and gatherings requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan but government recommends staying at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

Bhutan is gradually opening up. As of Mar 21:    All inter-district travels are allowed.  Domestic travellers from high-risk areas and districts can now undergo home quarantine and not facility quarantine. The quarantine duration is seven days until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403033854/https:/www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

All inter-district travels are allowed. Domestic travelers from high-risk areas and districts can now undergo home quarantine and not facility quarantine. The quarantine duration is seven days until further notice.    https://archive.ph/7bB3Z

Bhutan will undergo differentiated policy of quarantine next month. Starting April 25, quarantine period for international travellers who are fully vaccinated, with RT-PCR negative certificate will be reduced to five days. Those who are unvaccinated will have to undergo quarantine for 10 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319202750/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

Bhutan is gradually opening up.    The quarantine period for incoming (international) travellers will be reduced to five days starting April 4. The testing protocol will be revised accordingly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

For the international travellers, the lift of the 5 days quarantine will depend on the global lifting of the pandemic as per the Prime Minister. According to the Foreign Minister and Chairman of the Tourism Council of Bhutan (TCB), the country may allow quarantine-free entry by autumn this year should the situation continue to improve.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045842/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Vaccines are available for everyone above the age of 18 years.  After vaccinating 12-16 year old children, Bhutan is in the process of vaccinating 5-11 year old children and providing booster doses to children 12-16 years old    Vaccines that have been approved include Covishield (AstraZeneca), Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech, and Sinopharm and they are fully funded by the Govt.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319204124/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/11-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%B0%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%9D%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%95%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%A2/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045834/https://www.moh.gov.bt/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220402015515/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/24-03-33-covid-19-booster-vaccination-for-children-12-to-17-years-old/

Vaccines are available for everyone above the age of 18 years. After vaccinating 12-16-year-old children, Bhutan is in the process of vaccinating 5-11-year-old children and providing booster doses to children 12-16 years old. Vaccines that have been approved include Covishield (AstraZeneca), Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech, and Sinopharm and they are fully funded by the Govt.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160519/https://www.moh.gov.bt/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418161150/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/24-03-33-covid-19-booster-vaccination-for-children-12-to-17-years-old/

COVID 19 vaccines and boosters were prioritized for the elderly.  There is a COVID 19 hotline for senior citizens    https://web.archive.org/web/20210527034238/http://www.moh.gov.bt/announcement-senior-citizens/
COVID 19 vaccines and boosters were prioritized for the elderly. There is a COVID 19 hotline for senior citizens.    https://archive.ph/5gbLt

COVID-19 Non-vaccinated   Across the country, most states (e.g. Gujarat) have reopened schools at all levels. However, some states (e.g. Jammu) remain offline only at some levels (e.g. lower level classes).  /web/20220403181158/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/schools-colleges-to-go-100-offline-from-monday-in-gujarat/articleshow/89654848.cms  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403181359/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/schools-reopen-in-jammu-for-lower-classes-after-two-years/articleshow/89724169.cms    COVID-19 Vaccinated:  In some states (e.g. Punjab), only vaccinated children will be permitted to fully attend schools offline.  /web/20220403180131/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/only-vaccinated-children-will-be-allowed-in-schools/articleshow/88843251.cms

Domestic travel restrictions eased.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403205811/https://gulfnews.com/business/aviation/india-relaxes-covid-19-restrictions-for-international-and-domestic-flights-1.1648305385611

Commercial international flights resumed 27 March.  COVID-19 Non-vaccinated  Negative PCR test (min. 72 hours before boarding), no further quarantine and testing needed if unvaccinated.    COVID-19 Vaccinated  Proof of vaccination needed, no further quarantine and testing needed if vaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403184118/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/india/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403184040/https://www.travelandleisure.com/travel-news/india-to-resume-international-flights-after-2-years
No policy change.

No change noted.  "Comprehensive public information campaign to date; on various websites and platforms. Extensive statistics on COVID-19 cases, vaccinations and state measures are provided, and in multiple different languages, on a national and state level. Pages are usually updated daily.    For example:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220314105958/https://www.mygov.in/covid-19"

No change noted. Testing recommended only for symptomatic.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403183109/https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/is-testing-only-symptomatic-people-for-covid-right-strategy-what-experts-say-101642089092082.html

Contact tracing stopped; only symptomatic patients tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403182919/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/blogs/voices/why-india-needs-to-relax-the-mask-mandate/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403183109/https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/is-testing-only-symptomatic-people-for-covid-right-strategy-what-experts-say-101642089092082.html

No change in policy.  "Face masks are almost universally required to be worn in public, especially in urban areas, indoors, and on public transportation.  These regulations are being strictly enforced.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314104410/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/"

While most states (e.g. Maharashtra, Telangana) have removed the mandate on face masks in public spaces, face masks remain mandatory in some states (e.g. West Bengal).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403182303/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/covid19-update-states-where-covid-19-mask-not-mandatory-anymore-what-experts-have-to-say-11648797250096.html

No change noted.   "No general difference between elderly people and the rest of the population."  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403182303/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/covid19-update-states-where-covid-19-mask-not-mandatory-anymore-what-experts-have-to-say-11648797250096.html

No change in policy; additionally, 12-14 year olds begin getting vaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403182617/https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/covid-19-vaccine-for-ages-12-to-14-booster-jab-for-all-above-60-from-today-2825399

No change in policy.  Vaccines remain available in both private hospitals at an administrative cost and government hospitals free of cost.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220403185225/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/over-15-66-crore-covid-19-vaccine-doses-available-with-states-uts-centre/articleshow/90604440.cms

No change in policy.  "No policy change. No nationwide vaccine mandate imposed by national government, but some states have enacted such measures for teachers, students and university staff as a prerequisite for the reopening of schools and universities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314110720/https://www.timesnownews.com/education/article/delhi-schools-to-reopen-from-february-7-for-classes-9-to-12-ddma/855738  https://web.archive.org/web/20220314110835/https://www.newindianexpress.com/thesundaystandard/2022/feb/20/no-entry-without-vaccination-certificate-delhi-university-2421519.html"

Workplaces may function at full strength. However, authorities may enact stricter rules in areas at high risk for COVID-19 transmission. Nonessential businesses, except for specifically permitted industries, must close in these localities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible. Public gatherings remain banned, though enforcement and adherence vary by region.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible. Public gatherings remain banned, though enforcement and adherence vary by region.  Gampaha District limits participation in permitted gatherings like weddings to fully vaccinated people; other regions may enact similar curbs ahead of a proposed nationwide mandate for vaccination cards to enter most public venues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81    Maximum 75% of usual capacity for private indoor gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153155/http://www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/public/elfinder/files/feturesArtical/2022/Press%20Release%20on%20Public%20and%20Work%20Activities%20due%20to%20COVID_20220331.pdf

Public transport vehicles can run at 75 percent capacity with protocols, such as requiring all passengers to be seated and wear facemasks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

Public transport vehicles can run at 75 percent capacity with protocols, such as requiring all passengers to be seated and wear facemasks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

Fully vaccinated passengers are exempt from any on-arrival test or quarantine. Unvaccinated arrivals above 12 years old must take an on-arrival test, quarantine at home or a designated facility until the seventh day of arrival, and undergo an exit PCR or RAT test.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153531/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81
No further measures announced.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418154933/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

PCR and/or antigen tests available in Sri Lanka.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160903/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Close contacts are traced.    https://archive.ph/tO5G2

Face masks must be worn in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153155/http://www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/public/elfinder/files/feturesArtical/2022/Press%20Release%20on%20Public%20and%20Work%20Activities%20due%20to%20COVID_20220331.pdf

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    21 more million doses to be delivered before June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    According to MoH Nepal, as of mid March 2022, 75.4% of the population have received the 1st dose and 65% are fully vaccinated. Abour 7.2% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html
